Because in C++, the ! operator returns true (1) if the operand is zero, false (0) otherwise. So if a[j] has the i-th bit set, then (a[j] & (1 <<i)) is non-zero, so !(...) is 0. If the bit is not set, then (a[j] & ...) is zero, so !(...) is 1. So adding this to v gives the correct count. So the code inside the inner loop is:

v += !(a[j] & (1 << i)); But because of operator precedence, this is parsed as:

v += ( !(a[j] & (1 << i)) );

Which is correct. So the missing code is:

v += !(a[j] & (1 << i));

So inserting that line inside the inner loop (the for j loop) would make the code work correctly. Therefore, the line to be filled in the TODO is:

v += !(a[j] & (1 << i)); That's the correct code.
children.label: code_analysis
